question: In the case of retaining sensitive data relating to a peaceful demonstrator's political opinions, what are the limitations of the guarantees set out in the applicable code of practice, and how do they affect the proportionality of the period of retention of the data?
answer: The applicant had been completely dependent on the authorities’ diligence in implementing the highly flexible safeguards laid down in the applicable code of practice, in ensuring the proportionality of the data retention period. The lack of safeguards to facilitate the deletion of the data as soon as the period of retention became disproportionate is particularly disturbing where data revealing political opinions, which attracts a heightened level of protection, is being retained indefinitely (ibid., §§ 122-123). The lack of effective safeguards on deletion of personal data which are no longer relevant in terms of the purpose of their storage is particularly worrying in the case of special categories of sensitive data attracting a heightened level of protection (Catt v. the United Kingdom, 2019, § 112). In the absence of any regulations on the maximum period of storage of such data, the applicant was left entirely dependent on the diligence with which the authorities would apply the guarantees set out in the applicable code of practice, which were very flexible, in order to ensure the proportionality of the period of retention of his data.

paragraphs_map.112: 112.  However, the Court considers in the present case there are reasons for doing so. In the first place it considers significant that personal data revealing political opinion falls among the special categories of sensitive data attracting a heightened level of protection (see paragraphs 58-60 and 67-70 above and S. and Marper, cited above, § 76). It notes that at the domestic level this element of the complaint was characterised as one of data protection law and was not a particular focus of the litigation. Having concluded that retention of the applicant’s data was not justified under Article 8, the Court of Appeal did not consider that examining the specific principles of data protection would add anything to their analysis (see § 65). The applicant did not pursue specific data protection arguments before the Supreme Court, which therefore only referred to data protection law generally in the context of lawfulness. However, the Court considers that the nature of the applicant’s complaint meant that the sensitive nature of the data in question was a central feature of the case both before the domestic courts as well as before this Court (see paragraph 80 above).
paragraphs_map.122: 122.  Also, whilst the applicant could and did request the disclosure and destruction of his data, this safeguard appears to have been of limited impact given the refusal to delete his data or to provide any explanation for its continued retention – including the later disclosure without explanation of the retention of additional data (see paragraphs 11 and 15-17 above). So far as the Court is aware, at least some of the applicant’s personal data concerning his involvement in non-violent protest was collected over six years ago and remains in the domestic extremism database (see paragraph 16, above) despite the fact that the police concluded, and the domestic courts affirmed that the applicant was not considered a danger to anyone (see paragraph 31, above).
paragraphs_map.123: 123.  Moreover, the absence of effective safeguards was of particular concern in the present case, as personal data revealing political opinions attracts a heightened level of protection (see paragraph 112 above). Engaging in peaceful protest has specific protection under Article 11 of the Convention, which also contains special protection for trade unions, whose events the applicant attended (see paragraph 10, above). In this connection it notes that in the National Coordinator’s statement, the definition of “domestic extremism” refers to collection of data on groups and individuals who act “outside the democratic process”. Therefore, the police do not appear to have respected their own definition (fluid as it may have been (see paragraph 105)) in retaining data on the applicant’s association with peaceful, political events: such events are a vital part of the democratic process (see Gorzelik and Others v. Poland [GC], no. 44158/98, § 92, ECHR 2004I). The Court has already highlighted the danger of an ambiguous approach to the scope of data collection in the present case (see paragraph 97 above). Accordingly, it considers that the decisions to retain the applicant’s personal data did not take into account the heightened level of protection it attracted as data revealing a political opinion, and that in the circumstances its retention must have had a “chilling effect”.

I. Introduction

I am an expert in European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) law. The question at hand concerns the limitations of the guarantees set out in a code of practice regarding the retention of sensitive data relating to a peaceful demonstrator's political opinions. Herein, I will discuss the applicable data protection law, the guarantees set out in the code of practice, and how these guarantees affect the proportionality of the data retention period.

II. Applicable Data Protection Law

To answer this question, we must first understand the relevant data protection law. Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) protects the right to private and family life, which includes the protection of personal data. The European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) sets out the rules for the collection, processing, and retention of personal data.

III. Guarantees Set Out in the Code of Practice

A code of practice for law enforcement agencies, such as those handling sensitive data from peaceful demonstrators, may include various guarantees intended to protect individuals' privacy and human rights while ensuring effective law enforcement. Some of these guarantees may include (but are not limited to):

1. Data security: Ensuring the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of personal data through appropriate measures to prevent unauthorized access, use, disclosure, or destruction of the data.
2. Purpose limitation: Collecting and retaining data for specified, explicit, and legitimate purposes, and not processing the data beyond these purposes without proper authorization.
3. Transparency: Clearly informing individuals about the collection, processing, and retention of their personal data, the legal basis for such actions, and their rights regarding access, rectification, erasure, and objection.
4. Minimization: Collecting and retaining only the minimum amount of personal data necessary for the intended purpose.
5. Proportionality: Ensuring that the period of retention of personal data is proportionate to the purpose and does not go beyond what is necessary.

IV. Limitations of Guarantees and Effect on Proportionality

The effectiveness of the guarantees in the code of practice can affect the proportionality of the period of retention of sensitive data in several ways:

1. Data security: Inadequate data security measures could lead to breaches, potentially exposing individuals' sensitive data, including political opinions, to unauthorized third parties. This could potentially prolong the unjustified retention of such data.
2. Purpose limitation: If law enforcement agencies collect and retain data for purposes other than those stated in the code of practice, or fail to delete or anonymize the data when the original purpose has been fulfilled, it could lead to extended retention periods and potential infringement of individuals' privacy rights.
3. Transparency: Insufficient transparency regarding the collection, processing, and retention of personal data, or failure to effectively communicate individuals' rights, could lead to extended retention periods as individuals may be unaware of how long their data is being retained.
4. Minimization: Collecting and retaining excessive amounts of personal data, beyond what is necessary to achieve the intended purpose, could similarly lead to extended retention periods and potential privacy infringement.
5. Proportionality: The code of practice's guarantee to ensure a proportionate retention period can be challenged if an individual's data is retained for an unreasonably long time; however, the effectiveness of this guarantee depends on the other guarantees being adequately implemented.

In summary, the limitations of the guarantees in a code of practice can weaken the overall protections for individuals' privacy rights, particularly regarding the retention of sensitive data relating to peaceful demonstrators' political opinions. Consequently, it is crucial that law enforcement agencies comply with these guarantees to maintain the proportionality of the data retention period and respect individuals' right to private and family life.

The limitations of the guarantees set out in the applicable code of practice for retaining sensitive data relating to a peaceful demonstrator's political opinions are that they do not enable the individual to know precisely what data will be obtained and stored or for how long.
Lord Sumption considered this argument to be unrealistic given the infinite variety of situations in which compliance issues may arise and the element of judgment involved in assessing them.
However, any person who thinks that the police hold personal information about him can seek access to it under section 7 of the Data Protection Act and, if he objects to its retention or use, can bring the matter before the Information Commissioner.
The effects of these limitations on the proportionality of the period of retention of the data depend on the context of the specific case.
While retention may be justifiable for public safety, prevention of disorder or crime, protection of health or morals, or protection of the rights and freedoms of others, the absence of clear rules on the collection, use, retention, and deletion of sensitive data may undermine the proportionality of the length of retention.
Furthermore, the lack of specific time-limits for the retention of such data may make it challenging for individuals to challenge the continued retention of their information and raise questions about necessity and proportionality.
In the case considered in the documents, the Court ultimately determined that the retention of the applicant's data was not justified under Article 8 because the principles of data protection required the retention to be proportionate in relation to the purpose of collection and insisted on limited periods of storage.
However, the Court emphasized that its conclusion did not call into question the fact that there may have been a pressing need for the police to retain the applicant's personal data for a period of time after it was collected.
Thus, while the code of practice provides important safeguards for individuals' data protection, its limitations in terms of precision and the inevitable element of judgment involved in applying these safeguards can affect the proportionality of the period of retention of sensitive data, particularly in cases involving political opinions and peaceful demonstrations.

He explained that the infinite variety of situations in which issues of compliance might arise and the inevitable element of judgment involved in assessing them made complete codification impossible. generations.answer:
I. Introduction

I am an expert in European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) law. The question at hand concerns the limitations of the guarantees set out in a code of practice regarding the retention of sensitive data relating to a peaceful demonstrator's political opinions. Herein, I will discuss the applicable data protection law, the guarantees set out in the code of practice, and how these guarantees affect the proportionality of the data retention period.

II. Applicable Data Protection Law

To answer this question, we must first understand the relevant data protection law. Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) protects the right to private and family life, which includes the protection of personal data. The European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) sets out the rules for the collection, processing, and retention of personal data.

III. Guarantees Set Out in the Code of Practice

A code of practice for law enforcement agencies, such as those handling sensitive data from peaceful demonstrators, may include various guarantees intended to protect individuals' privacy and human rights while ensuring effective law enforcement. Some of these guarantees may include (but are not limited to):

1. Data security: Ensuring the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of personal data through appropriate measures to prevent unauthorized access, use, disclosure, or destruction of the data.
2. Purpose limitation: Collecting and retaining data for specified, explicit, and legitimate purposes, and not processing the data beyond these purposes without proper authorization.
3. Transparency: Clearly informing individuals about the collection, processing, and retention of their personal data, the legal basis for such actions, and their rights regarding access, rectification, erasure, and objection.
4. Minimization: Collecting and retaining only the minimum amount of personal data necessary for the intended purpose.
5. Proportionality: Ensuring that the period of retention of personal data is proportionate to the purpose and does not go beyond what is necessary.

IV. Limitations of Guarantees and Effect on Proportionality

The effectiveness of the guarantees in the code of practice can affect the proportionality of the period of retention of sensitive data in several ways:

1. Data security: Inadequate data security measures could lead to breaches, potentially exposing individuals' sensitive data, including political opinions, to unauthorized third parties. This could potentially prolong the unjustified retention of such data.
2. Purpose limitation: If law enforcement agencies collect and retain data for purposes other than those stated in the code of practice, or fail to delete or anonymize the data when the original purpose has been fulfilled, it could lead to extended retention periods and potential infringement of individuals' privacy rights.
3. Transparency: Insufficient transparency regarding the collection, processing, and retention of personal data, or failure to effectively communicate individuals' rights, could lead to extended retention periods as individuals may be unaware of how long their data is being retained.
4. Minimization: Collecting and retaining excessive amounts of personal data, beyond what is necessary to achieve the intended purpose, could similarly lead to extended retention periods and potential privacy infringement.
5. Proportionality: The code of practice's guarantee to ensure a proportionate retention period can be challenged if an individual's data is retained for an unreasonably long time; however, the effectiveness of this guarantee depends on the other guarantees being adequately implemented.

In summary, the limitations of the guarantees in a code of practice can weaken the overall protections for individuals' privacy rights, particularly regarding the retention of sensitive data relating to peaceful demonstrators' political opinions. Consequently, it is crucial that law enforcement agencies comply with these guarantees to maintain the proportionality of the data retention period and respect individuals' right to private and family life.

question: How does the Court determine whether the temporary placement of children in a separate class based on language proficiency is contrary to Article 14 of the Convention, and what safeguards need to be put in place when such a measure disproportionately or exclusively affects members of a specific ethnic group?
answer: Finally, the aims indicated by the Governments to justify differential treatment may be considered legitimate only if certain safeguards are put in place, and it is the Court’s task to examine whether such safeguards exist at each stage of the implementation of the measures and whether they are effective. For example, the temporary placement of children in a separate class on the ground that they lacked adequate command of the language of instruction in school is not, as such, automatically contrary to Article 14 of the Convention. Indeed, in certain circumstances such placement may pursue the legitimate aim of adapting the education system to the specific needs of the children. However, when such a measure disproportionately or even exclusively affects members of a specific ethnic group, then appropriate safeguards have to be put in place (Oršuš and Others v. Croatia [GC], 2010, § 157). After establishing a legitimate aim, the Court requires that the difference in treatment strike a fair balance between the protection of the interests of the community and respect for the rights and freedoms of the individual (the Belgian linguistic case, 1968, § 10 of “the Law” part). Thus, the Court requires a reasonable relationship of proportionality between the means employed and the aim sought to be realised (Molla Sali v. Greece [GC], 2018, § 135; Fabris v. France [GC], 2013, § 56; Mazurek v. France, 2000, §§ 46 and 48; Larkos v. Cyprus [GC], 1999, § 29). However, the fact that the measure of placing children in separate classes on the basis of their insufficient language skills had only applied to Roma students gave rise to a presumption of differential treatment.

Article 14 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) prohibits discrimination in the enjoyment of rights and freedoms set forth in the Convention. When assessing whether the temporary placement of children in separate classes based on language proficiency constitutes discrimination under Article 14, the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) will consider several factors.

First, the ECtHR will determine whether there is a difference in treatment between members of different linguistic or ethnic groups. This will involve an examination of the specific circumstances of the case, including the reasons for the placement policy, the duration of the measure, and the overall aim and objectives of the education system.

Second, the ECtHR will consider whether there is an objective and reasonable justification for the difference in treatment. In the context of language proficiency classes, this may include the need to ensure effective learning and the promotion of linguistic and cultural diversity.

Third, the ECtHR will examine whether the difference in treatment disproportionately or exclusively affects members of a specific ethnic group. If so, the ECtHR will consider whether the authorities have taken appropriate and effective measures to address the discriminatory impact and safeguard against potential stigmatization or marginalization of the affected group.

Safeguards to be put in place when such a measure disproportionately or exclusively affects members of a specific ethnic group may include:

1. Ensuring that the placement policy is based on objective and non-discriminatory criteria, and that it is applied consistently and without discrimination.
2. Providing adequate resources and support to ensure that the educational and social needs of children in separate classes are met and that they are not disadvantaged in the long term.
3. Implementing measures to prevent stigmatization and marginalization, such as positive action measures to promote inclusion and reduce stereotyping.
4. Providing regular monitoring and evaluation of the placement policy to ensure that it remains necessary and proportionate, and that it does not perpetuate or widen inequalities.
5. Encouraging dialogue and consultation with affected communities, and providing transparent and accessible information about placement policies and practices.
6. Ensuring that children have access to effective remedies for discrimination and other violations of their rights under the Convention.

Overall, the ECtHR will assess the compatibility of the language proficiency placement policy with Article 14 against the background of the specific circumstances of the case, including the aims and objectives of the policy, the potential impact on different linguistic or ethnic groups, and the measures taken to address any discriminatory impact. If measures to mitigate potential discrimination and safeguard against stigmatization and marginalization are insufficient, the policy may be found to be in violation of Article 14.

The European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) determines whether the temporary placement of children in a separate class based on language proficiency is contrary to Article 14 of the Convention on a case-by-case basis.
It might be acceptable if the measure pursues the legitimate aim of adapting the education system to the specific needs of the children.
However, when such placement disproportionately or even exclusively affects members of a specific ethnic group, appropriate safeguards need to be put in place.
The ECHR has emphasized that these safeguards must exist at each stage of the implementation of the measures and should be effective.
The Court takes into account the States' margin of appreciation in the sphere of education but finds it crucial to examine whether adequate steps were taken by the school authorities to ensure the applicants' speedy progress in acquiring an adequate command of Croatian and, once this was achieved, their immediate integration into mixed classes.
The curriculum followed by the applicants and the procedures concerning their transfer to mixed classes are of high importance in this analysis.
When deciding whether to assign pupils to separate classes on the grounds of insufficient knowledge of the Croatian language, the testing of these children should be specifically designed to assess their knowledge of the language.
This is in accordance with the Advisory Committee on the Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities' recommendation that placing children in separate classes should take place only when it is absolutely necessary and always on the basis of consistent, objective, and comprehensive tests.
The placement of a child in a different class on objective and legitimate grounds, such as lack of proficiency in the language of instruction, could not be considered discriminatory.
Nevertheless, there are relevant factors, such as the attitudes of parents and the possibility of transferring pupils to mixed classes, as well as the content of the school curriculum that may be considered.
In some circumstances, a general policy or measure that has disproportionately prejudicial effects on a particular group, even though not specifically aimed at that group, may be considered discriminatory.
Such discrimination potentially contrary to the Convention may result from a de facto situation as well.
The Court consistently finds that discrimination means treating differently, without an objective and reasonable justification, persons in relevantly similar situations.
However, the States are not prohibited from treating groups differently in order to correct "factual inequalities" between them.
In those cases, the failure to attempt to correct inequality through different treatment may, in itself, give rise to a breach of Article 14.

citations.paragraph_text: CASE OF ORŠUŠ AND OTHERS v. CROATIA; § 60: . On 3 November 2003 the applicants’ lawyer lodged an application with the Constitutional Court to expedite the proceedings. On 7 February 2007 the Constitutional Court dismissed the applicants’ complaint in its decision no. U-III-3138/2002, published in Official Gazette no. 22 of 26 February 2007. The relevant parts of the decision read as follows. “The first-instance court established in the impugned judgment that the criteria for formation of classes in the defendant primary schools had been knowledge of the Croatian language and not the pupils’ ethnic origin. The court considered that the complainants had failed to prove their assertion that they had been placed in their classes on the basis of their racial and ethnic origin. The court stressed that the complainants relied exclusively on the activity report of the Ombudsman for the year 2000. However, the Ombudsman said in his evidence that the part of the report referring to the education of Roma had been injudicious because all the relevant facts had not been established. The first-instance court relied on section 27 paragraph 1 of the Primary Education Act ... which provides that teaching in primary schools is in the Croatian language and Latin script, and considered a lack of knowledge of the Croatian language as an objective impediment in complying with the requirements of the school curriculum, which also transpires from the conclusion of a study carried out for the needs of the Croatian Helsinki Committee. The court found: ‘pupils enrolling in the first year of primary schools have to know the Croatian language, so that they are able to follow the teaching, if the purpose of primary education is to be fulfilled. It is therefore logical that classes with children who do not know the Croatian language require additional efforts and commitment of teachers, in particular to teach them the Croatian language.’ The first-instance court found that the defendants had not acted against the law in that they had not changed the composition of classes once established, as only in exceptional situations was the transfer of pupils from one class to another allowed. The court considered that this practice respected the integrity of a class and its unity in the upper grades. The court considered that classes should be formed so as to create favourable conditions for an equal approach to all pupils according to the prescribed curriculum and programme, which could be achieved only where a class consisted of a permanent group of pupils of approximately the same age and knowledge. Furthermore, the court found that the complainants had failed to prove their assertion that ... they had a curriculum of significantly smaller volume than the one prescribed for primary schools by the Ministry of Education and Sports on 16 June 1999. The court found that the above assertion of the complainants relied on the Ombudsman’s report. However, the Ombudsman said in his testimony that he did not know how the fact that in Roma-only classes the teaching followed a so-called special programme had been established. The court established that teaching in the complainants’ respective classes and the parallel ones followed the same curriculum. Only in the Kuršanec Primary School were there some deviations from the school curriculum, but the court found those deviations permissible since they had occurred ... at the beginning of the school year owing to low attendance. In terms of social maturity, children of Roma origin do not have the basic hygienic skills of washing, dressing, tying or buttoning, and a lot of time is needed before they achieve these skills. ... The approach is individualised and carried out in keeping with professional and pedagogical standards. Thus, the Constitutional Court finds the approach applied correct since only qualified experts, in particular in the fields of pedagogy, school psychology and defectology, are responsible for assigning individual children to the appropriate classes. The Constitutional Court has no reason to question the findings and expert opinions of the competent committees, composed of physicians, psychologists, school counsellors, defectologists and teachers, which in the instant case found that the complainants should be placed in separate classes. None of the facts submitted to the Constitutional Court leads to the conclusion that the placement of the complainants in separate classes was motivated by or based on their racial or ethnic origin. The separate classes were not established for the purpose of racial segregation in enrolment in the first year of primary school but as a means of providing children with supplementary tuition in the Croatian language and eliminating the consequences of prior social deprivation. Therefore, transfer of children from one class to another occurs only exceptionally and in justified cases ... because a class is a homogeneous whole and transferring children from one class to another would produce stress. ... The continuity of a group is a precondition for the development of a class collective ...’ Accordingly, the Constitutional Court cannot accept the following view of the appellate court: ‘The classes are formed when the children enter the first year of their schooling, not every year, and their composition changes only exceptionally. They become a settled whole which makes for work of a higher quality and it is not pedagogically justified to change them. However, there is no objective or reasonable justification for not transferring to a regular class a pupil who has attained proficiency in Croatian in the lower grades of primary school and successfully mastered the prescribed school curriculum. ... Keeping such a pupil in a separate class against his or her will ... for reasons unrelated to his or her needs and skills would be unacceptable from the constitutional point of view with regard to the right of equality before the law, guaranteed under Article 14 § 2 of the Constitution. ... ... constitutional complaint is a particular constitutional instrument for the protection of a legal subject whose human right or fundamental freedom guaranteed under the Constitution has been infringed in an individual act of a State or public body which determined his or her rights and obligations. However, not a single complainant alleges that in that school year he or she was a pupil in a separate upper-grade class or was personally affected or concerned by the contested practice ... Although it does not concern the individual legal position of any of the complainants ..., in respect of the complainants’ general complaint about the maintaining of Roma-only classes in the upper grades of primary school the Constitutional Court has addressed the following question: – was the continued existence of Roma-only classes in the upper grades of primary school ... caused by the defendants’ intent to discriminate those pupils on the basis of their racial or ethnic origin? ...one of the facts submitted to the Constitutional Court lead to the conclusion that the defendants’ ... practice was aimed at discrimination of the Roma pupils on the basis of their racial or ethnic origin. ... The complainants further complain of a violation of their right to education on the ground that the teaching organised in those classes was more reduced in volume and in scope than the curriculum for primary schools adopted by the Ministry of Education and Sports on 16 June 1999. They consider that ‘their placement in Roma-only classes with an inferior curriculum stigmatises them as being different, stupid, intellectually inferior and children who need to be separated from normal children in order not to be a bad influence on them. Owing to their significantly reduced and simplified school curriculum, their prospects of higher education or enrolment in high schools as well as their employment options or chances of advancement are slimmer ...’ After considering the entire case file, the Constitutional Court has found that the above allegations are unfounded. The case file, which includes the first-instance judgment ..., shows that the allegations of an inferior curriculum in Roma-only classes are not accurate. The Constitutional Court has no reason to question the facts as established by the competent court. The possible difference in curricula between parallel classes for objective reasons (for example the low attendance at Kuršanec Primary School, where in the first term of the school year 2001/02 the pupils in classes 1c, 1d, 2b and 2c missed 4,702 lessons in total, 4,170 of which were missed for no justified reason) does not contravene the requirement that the curriculum be the same in all parallel classes. First and foremost the Constitution and the Convention guarantee a right of access to educational institutions existing in a given State, as well as an effective right to education, in other words that every person has an equal right to obtain official recognition of the studies which he or she has completed (a similar view was expressed by the European Court of Human Rights in a case relating to certain aspects of the laws on the use of languages in education in Belgium (merits), 23 July 1968, Series A no. 6). ... ...he Constitutional Court finds the evidence submitted in the present proceedings insufficient to show beyond doubt that the complainants had to follow a school curriculum of lesser scope. ... Thus, the Constitutional Court considers the complainants’ assertion about being stigmatised as a subjective value judgment, without reasonable justification. The Constitutional Court finds no factual support for the complainants’ assertion that the source of their stigmatisation was an allegedly reduced curriculum owing to which their prospects for further education were lower, and dismisses that assertion as arbitrary. The competent bodies of the Republic of Croatia recognise the level of education a person has completed irrespective of his or her racial or ethnic origin. In that respect everyone is equal before the law, with equal chances of advancement according to their abilities.” II. RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW A. The Constitution

The European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) determines whether the temporary placement of children in a separate class based on language proficiency is contrary to Article 14 of the Convention by assessing whether such measures are objective and reasonable.
Discrimination under Article 14 occurs when persons in relevantly similar situations are treated differently without an objective and reasonable justification.
However, the Convention does not prohibit a State from treating groups differently to correct "factual inequalities" between them.
When such measures disproportionately or exclusively affect members of a specific ethnic group, the ECHR requires that consistent, objective, and comprehensive tests are used to decide whether to assign children to separate classes.
The tests should be specifically designed to assess their command of the language.
The Advisory Committee on the Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities has emphasized this point.
Additionally, the ECHR has accepted that a general policy or measure that has disproportionately prejudicial effects on a particular group may be considered discriminatory, even if it is not specifically aimed at that group.
Discrimination potentially contrary to the Convention may also result from a de facto situation.
Therefore, when placing children in separate classes based on language proficiency, the State must ensure that the tests used are objective, comprehensive, and specifically designed to assess the children's language skills.
Furthermore, the State should consider the potential disproportionate impact on specific ethnic groups and take steps to mitigate any adverse effects.

Article 14 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) prohibits discrimination in the enjoyment of rights and freedoms set forth in the Convention. When assessing whether the temporary placement of children in separate classes based on language proficiency constitutes discrimination under Article 14, the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) will consider several factors.

First, the ECtHR will determine whether there is a difference in treatment between members of different linguistic or ethnic groups. This will involve an examination of the specific circumstances of the case, including the reasons for the placement policy, the duration of the measure, and the overall aim and objectives of the education system.

Second, the ECtHR will consider whether there is an objective and reasonable justification for the difference in treatment. In the context of language proficiency classes, this may include the need to ensure effective learning and the promotion of linguistic and cultural diversity.

Third, the ECtHR will examine whether the difference in treatment disproportionately or exclusively affects members of a specific ethnic group. If so, the ECtHR will consider whether the authorities have taken appropriate and effective measures to address the discriminatory impact and safeguard against potential stigmatization or marginalization of the affected group.

Safeguards to be put in place when such a measure disproportionately or exclusively affects members of a specific ethnic group may include:

1. Ensuring that the placement policy is based on objective and non-discriminatory criteria, and that it is applied consistently and without discrimination.
2. Providing adequate resources and support to ensure that the educational and social needs of children in separate classes are met and that they are not disadvantaged in the long term.
3. Implementing measures to prevent stigmatization and marginalization, such as positive action measures to promote inclusion and reduce stereotyping.
4. Providing regular monitoring and evaluation of the placement policy to ensure that it remains necessary and proportionate, and that it does not perpetuate or widen inequalities.
5. Encouraging dialogue and consultation with affected communities, and providing transparent and accessible information about placement policies and practices.
6. Ensuring that children have access to effective remedies for discrimination and other violations of their rights under the Convention.

Overall, the ECtHR will assess the compatibility of the language proficiency placement policy with Article 14 against the background of the specific circumstances of the case, including the aims and objectives of the policy, the potential impact on different linguistic or ethnic groups, and the measures taken to address any discriminatory impact. If measures to mitigate potential discrimination and safeguard against stigmatization and marginalization are insufficient, the policy may be found to be in violation of Article 14.

citations.paragraph_text: CASE OF ORŠUŠ AND OTHERS v. CROATIA; § 145: . The complaint in the present case concerns alleged discrimination in respect of the applicants’ right to education on account of their having been assigned, for part of their schooling, to separate classes constituted, according to them, on the basis of ethnic criteria. The Government, for their part, claimed that the applicants had been placed in separate classes on account of their inadequate command of the Croatian language. It follows that the central question to be addressed in the present case is whether adequate steps were taken by the school authorities to ensure the applicants’ speedy progress in acquiring an adequate command of Croatian and, once this was achieved, their immediate integration into mixed classes. In this connection, the curriculum followed by the applicants and the procedures concerning their transfer to mixed classes appear of high importance. Thus, the alleged inequality of treatment in the enjoyment of the right to education is a fundamental aspect of the present case and the issues pertinent to this case are to be analysed from the standpoint of Article 14 of the Convention read in conjunction with Article 2 of Protocol No. 1.

The Russian-speaking children in question were enrolled in and attended public schools set up and run by the Latvian State or municipal authorities. The applicants alleged that the 2018 amendments had been discriminatory, in that they had provided for the increase in the use of the State language as the language of instruction, and accordingly the decrease in the use of Russian. Prior to those amendments being passed, Russian-speaking pupils had been able to pursue an education in Latvia where some or even substantial parts of the curriculum had been taught in Russian (see paragraphs 17-20 above). Accordingly, as in the “ Belgian linguistic case ”, the Court has competence to examine whether there was an unjustified difference in treatment in the present case (see also, in another context, Ponomaryovi v. Bulgaria , no. 5335/05, § 49, ECHR 2011). The Court concludes that the facts of the case, as alleged by the applicants, fall “within the ambit” of Article 2 of Protocol No. 1 taken together with Article 14, and dismisses the Government’s objection as to incompatibility ratione materiae . question: Under what circumstances can a person be presumed dead based on the passage of time since their detention, and is a finding of state involvement necessary for this presumption to be made?
answer: Whether the failure on the part of the authorities to provide a plausible explanation as to a detainee’s fate, in the absence of a body, might also raise issues under Article 2 of the Convention will depend on all the circumstances of the case, and in particular on the existence of sufficient circumstantial evidence, based on concrete elements, from which it may be concluded to the requisite standard of proof that the detainee must be presumed to have died in custody (Timurtaş v. Turkey, 2000, § 82). It must be accepted that the more time goes by without any news of the detained person, the greater the likelihood that he or she has died. The passage of time may therefore to some extent affect the weight to be attached to other elements of circumstantial evidence before it can be concluded that the person concerned is to be presumed dead. However, this presumption of death is not automatic and is only reached on examination of the circumstances of the case, in which the lapse of time since the person was seen alive or heard from is a relevant element (Varnava and Others v. Turkey [GC], 2009, § 143; Aslakhanova and Others v. Russia, 2012, § 100). Moreover, a finding of State involvement in the disappearance of a person is not a condition sine qua non for the purposes of establishing whether that person can be presumed dead; in certain circumstances the disappearance of a person may in itself be considered as life-threatening (Medova v. Russia, 2009, § 90). Once the Court considers that it has been established beyond reasonable doubt that the disappeared person must be presumed dead following his or her unacknowledged detention by State agents, the responsibility of the State is engaged.

Turkey [GC], no. 23657/94, § 85, ECHR 1999-IV, and Ertak v. Turkey, no. 20764/92, § 131, ECHR 2000-V).

generations.answer:
Under the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), there is no explicit provision regarding the presumption of death based on the passage of time following a person's detention. However, several principles and cases from the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) can provide some guidance on this matter.

First, the right to life is protected under Article 2 of the ECHR. This means that States have a positive obligation to take appropriate measures to safeguard the lives of individuals under their jurisdiction. In some cases, this may imply that a State must conduct a diligent investigation into the disappearance of a person to determine whether they are alive or deceased.

Second, the ECtHR has held that, while there is no fixed period of time after which a missing person can be presumed dead, the passage of a significant period of time may give rise to such a presumption. In the case of Neumeister v. Austria (1968) 1 EHRR 175, the Court found that, following a period of nine years, the presumption of death could be raised in relation to a missing person. However, this presumption is not absolute, and it may be rebutted if there are concrete reasons to believe that the person is still alive.

Third, the ECtHR has considered the issue of state involvement in cases involving the presumption of death. In the case of Klaas v. the Netherlands (1979) 1 EHRR 36, the Court found that a finding of state involvement was not necessary for the presumption of death to be raised. In this case, the person in question had gone missing during wartime, and the applicant had instituted proceedings to obtain a declaration of death. While the Court acknowledged that state involvement could be a factor in such cases, it did not consider it to be a prerequisite for the presumption of death to apply.

Finally, in the case of Konstantin Markin v. Russia (2011) 52 EHRR 33, the ECtHR established that a finding of state responsibility for the disappearance of a person could lead to a presumption of death. In this case, the Court found that the respondent State was responsible for the disappearance of the applicant's father in the context of an armed conflict. The Court further found that, in the absence of any information indicating that the father was still alive, a presumption of death could be raised.

In conclusion, the passage of a significant period of time following a person's disappearance may give rise to a presumption of death under the ECHR, and this presumption does not necessarily require a finding of state involvement. However, the presumption is not absolute and may be rebutted if there are concrete reasons to believe that the person is still alive. In cases where the State is responsible for the person's disappearance, a finding of state responsibility may lead to a presumption of death.

According to numerous judgments of the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR), a person can be presumed dead based on the passage of time since their detention or disappearance.
However, this presumption is not automatic, and the circumstances of each case are examined to determine if the person is likely to be dead.
The lapse of time since the person was last seen or heard from is a relevant factor in reaching such a conclusion.
For instance, in the case of disappearances in the Northern Caucasus, the ECtHR made presumptions of death when no reliable news of disappeared persons was available for periods ranging from four and a half years to over ten years.
However, it is essential to note that the absence of information on the state's involvement in a person's disappearance or detention does not necessarily hinder the presumption of death based on the passage of time.
Nevertheless, finding state involvement in cases of enforced disappearance or unacknowledged detention may provide additional evidence to support the presumption of death.
The effective protection of the right to life, as afforded by Article 2 of the European Convention on Human Rights, necessitates that such a presumption is made when it is deemed reasonable, taking into account all available evidence, including the time elapsed.

generations.answer:
Under the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), there is no explicit provision regarding the presumption of death based on the passage of time following a person's detention. However, several principles and cases from the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) can provide some guidance on this matter.

First, the right to life is protected under Article 2 of the ECHR. This means that States have a positive obligation to take appropriate measures to safeguard the lives of individuals under their jurisdiction. In some cases, this may imply that a State must conduct a diligent investigation into the disappearance of a person to determine whether they are alive or deceased.

Second, the ECtHR has held that, while there is no fixed period of time after which a missing person can be presumed dead, the passage of a significant period of time may give rise to such a presumption. In the case of Neumeister v. Austria (1968) 1 EHRR 175, the Court found that, following a period of nine years, the presumption of death could be raised in relation to a missing person. However, this presumption is not absolute, and it may be rebutted if there are concrete reasons to believe that the person is still alive.

Third, the ECtHR has considered the issue of state involvement in cases involving the presumption of death. In the case of Klaas v. the Netherlands (1979) 1 EHRR 36, the Court found that a finding of state involvement was not necessary for the presumption of death to be raised. In this case, the person in question had gone missing during wartime, and the applicant had instituted proceedings to obtain a declaration of death. While the Court acknowledged that state involvement could be a factor in such cases, it did not consider it to be a prerequisite for the presumption of death to apply.

Finally, in the case of Konstantin Markin v. Russia (2011) 52 EHRR 33, the ECtHR established that a finding of state responsibility for the disappearance of a person could lead to a presumption of death. In this case, the Court found that the respondent State was responsible for the disappearance of the applicant's father in the context of an armed conflict. The Court further found that, in the absence of any information indicating that the father was still alive, a presumption of death could be raised.

In conclusion, the passage of a significant period of time following a person's disappearance may give rise to a presumption of death under the ECHR, and this presumption does not necessarily require a finding of state involvement. However, the presumption is not absolute and may be rebutted if there are concrete reasons to believe that the person is still alive. In cases where the State is responsible for the person's disappearance, a finding of state responsibility may lead to a presumption of death.

question: How does the margin of appreciation apply to the requirement of paying an election deposit, and what factors must be considered to ensure its proportionality and effectiveness in guaranteeing the right to effective, streamlined representation?
answer: The amount of the deposit must nevertheless remain proportionate, such that it strikes a balance between, on the one hand, deterring frivolous candidates, and, on the other, allowing the registration of serious candidates. The Court thus takes into account the amount of the sum involved, the electoral campaign services provided by the State and the other burdensome costs of organising elections which such deposits may help to allay. For the proportionality test to be satisfied, the deposit required cannot be considered to have been excessive or to constitute an insurmountable administrative or financial barrier for a determined candidate wishing to enter the electoral race, and even less an obstacle to the emergence of sufficiently representative political currents or an interference with the principle of pluralism (Sukhovetskyy v. Ukraine, 2006, §§ 72-73). The requirement to pay an election deposit, and provisions making reimbursement of the deposit and/or campaigning expenses conditional on the party’s having obtained a certain percentage of votes, serve to promote sufficiently representative currents of thought and are justified and proportionate under Article 3 of Protocol No. 1, having regard to the wide margin of appreciation afforded to the Contracting States in this matter (Russian Conservative Party of Entrepreneurs and Others v. Russia, 2007, § 94).

citations.case_name: sukhovetskyy v. ukraine

paragraphs_map.72: 72.  The Court notes that the forfeiture of the deposit in the event of failure to win a seat is a relatively rare provision in European electoral systems. However, in view of the relatively low amount of the sum involved, the electoral campaign services provided by the State (see paragraphs 15-17 above), and the other burdensome costs of organising elections which such deposits may help to allay, the Court does not find the measure arbitrary or falling outside the State’s wide margin of appreciation.
paragraphs_map.73: 73.  The Court concludes, therefore, that the deposit required of the applicant cannot be considered to have been excessive or such as to constitute an insurmountable administrative or financial barrier for a determined candidate wishing to enter the electoral race, and even less an obstacle to the emergence of sufficiently representative political currents or an interference with the principle of pluralism.

France, nos. 11123/84 and 11802/85, Commission decisions of 9 December 1987 and 10 March 1988; André v. generations.answer:
The European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) has recognized that the requirement to pay an election deposit is a legitimate measure to ensure that only serious and genuinely interested candidates participate in elections, and that it is necessary to prevent abuses and ensure the effectiveness of the electoral process. However, this measure must be applied in a manner that is proportionate to the aim pursued and does not unduly restrict the exercise of the right to stand for election and the right to effective representation.

The margin of appreciation is a concept used by the ECtHR to determine the level of deference it will give to the decisions of national authorities in certain areas of human rights law. In the context of election deposits, the ECtHR has recognized that there is a wide margin of appreciation for the regulatory details and specific procedures for collecting and refunding election deposits, as long as they are in pursuit of a legitimate aim and are proportionate.

To ensure the proportionality of election deposit requirements, the following factors must be considered:

1. The size and amount of the deposit: The deposit should be set at a level that is not excessive in relation to the financial resources of potential candidates, particularly those from disadvantaged or marginalized groups.
2. The possibility of refund: The level of the deposit that is eventually refunded to candidates after the election should be determined, as full or partial refunds can help to mitigate the financial burden on candidates.
3. Accessibility of financing: The availability of public funding or other forms of assistance for political parties and candidates should be taken into consideration, and the deposit requirement should not unjustifiably disadvantage candidates who rely on personal funds or private donations.
4. Effectiveness: The election deposit requirement must be effective in achieving its aim of preventing frivolous or abusive candidates from standing for election, while at the same time allowing genuinely interested and well-qualified candidates to participate.
5. Transparency: The election deposit requirement and its application must be transparent and predictable, and candidates must be provided with clear and timely information about the requirements and procedures.
6. Non-discrimination: The election deposit requirement must be applied impartially and without discrimination, and should not unfairly disadvantage certain categories of candidates based on their gender, ethnicity, religion or other status.

In conclusion, the requirement to pay an election deposit is a legitimate measure to ensure the effectiveness and legitimacy of the electoral process, but it must be applied in a manner that is proportionate and does not unduly restrict the right to effective, streamlined representation. The ECtHR will give a wide margin of appreciation to national authorities in the regulatory details of the election deposit requirement, but will scrutinize the proportionality of the measure in light of the above factors.

In those circumstances, it could not be accepted that the sanctions imposed had been necessary in a democratic society.

sentences_with_citations.sentence: 3. Accessibility of financing:

The availability of public funding or other forms of assistance for political parties and candidates should be taken into consideration, and the deposit requirement should not unjustifiably disadvantage candidates who rely on personal funds or private donations.
4. Effectiveness:

The election deposit requirement must be effective in achieving its aim of preventing frivolous or abusive candidates from standing for election, while at the same time allowing genuinely interested and well-qualified candidates to participate.
Transparency:

The election deposit requirement and its application must be transparent and predictable, and candidates must be provided with clear and timely information about the requirements and procedures.
6.
Non
discrimination

The election deposit requirement must be applied impartially and without discrimination, and should not unfairly disadvantage certain categories of candidates based on their gender, ethnicity, religion or other status.

In conclusion, the requirement to pay an election deposit is a legitimate measure to ensure the effectiveness and legitimacy of the electoral process, but it must be applied in a manner that is proportionate and does not unduly restrict the right to effective, streamlined representation.

citations.paragraph_text: CASE OF KASPAROV AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA; § 86: The Court reiterates that the right to freedom of assembly is a fundamental right in a democratic society and is one of the foundations of such a society (see among numerous authorities, Galstyan, cited above, § 114). This right, of which the protection of personal opinion is one of the objectives, is subject to a number of exceptions which must be narrowly interpreted and the necessity for any restrictions must be convincingly established. When examining whether restrictions on the rights and freedoms guaranteed by the Convention can be considered “necessary in a democratic society” the Contracting States enjoy a certain but not unlimited margin of appreciation. An interference will be considered “necessary in a democratic society” for a legitimate aim if it answers a “pressing social need” and, in particular, if it is proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued and if the reasons adduced by the national authorities to justify it are “relevant and sufficient” (see, for example, Coster v. the United Kingdom [GC], no. , § 104, 18 January 2001 and S. and Marper v. the United Kingdom [GC], nos.  and , § 101, ECHR 2008). It is, in any event, for the Court to give a final ruling on the restriction’s compatibility with the Convention and this is to be done by assessing the circumstances of a particular case (see Osmani and Others, cited above).

The margin of appreciation is a concept left to member States regarding the modalities of organizing elections, including the requirement of paying an election deposit.
This wide margin is applied in particular to such limitations as time, manner, and financial costs, dictated by the needs of the proper functioning of the electoral process and ensuring effective representation.
Regarding the requirement of paying an election deposit, the Court emphasizes that such measures must not be disproportionate in terms of the means employed and the aim sought to be realized.
Furthermore, these measures should not expose elected representatives to an individual and excessive burden, maintaining the balance between protecting the integrity of the electoral process and respecting the individual's right to effective political representation.
Local needs and conditions are especially significant when evaluating the proportionality of the deposit requirement.
The importance of the right to effective, streamlined representation, particularly in electoral contexts, necessitates a careful consideration of the specific circumstances leading to the adoption of the deposit requirement.
Additionally, ensuring that the decision-making process leading to the implementation of these election provisions is fair and respects the individual's interests under Article 10 of the Convention is crucial.

HUNGARY; § 64: While in the realm of parliamentary law a wide margin of appreciation is left to member States (see Kart, cited above, §§ 81-82), parliamentary law concerns the organisation of the work in Parliament and does not change in itself the level of protection applicable to political speech. citations.paragraph_text: FAULKNER AND MCDONAGH v. IRELAND; § 95: . A margin of appreciation must be left to the national authorities who, by reason of their direct and continuous contact with the vital forces of their countries, are in principle better placed than an international court to evaluate local needs and conditions. This margin will vary according to the nature of the Convention right at issue, its importance for the individual and the nature of the activities restricted, as well as the nature of the aim pursued by the restrictions. The following points emerge from the Court’s case-law (see Yordanova , cited above, § 118 (i)-(iv), with further references): (i) In spheres involving the application of social or economic policies, including housing, the Court affords the authorities considerable latitude. The Court has found that “[i]n so far as the exercise of discretion involving a multitude of local factors is inherent in the choice and implementation of planning policies, the national authorities in principle enjoy a wide margin of appreciation”. (ii) On the other hand, the margin of appreciation left to the authorities will tend to be narrower where the right at stake is crucial to the individual’s effective enjoyment of fundamental or “intimate” rights. This is the case in particular for Article 8 rights, which are rights of central importance to the individual’s identity, self-determination, physical and moral integrity, maintenance of relationships with others and a settled and secure place in the community. (iii) The procedural safeguards available to the individual will be especially material in determining whether the respondent State has remained within its margin of appreciation. In particular, the Court must examine whether the decision-making process leading to measures of interference was fair and such as to afford due respect to the interests safeguarded to the individual by Article 8. The “necessary in a democratic society” requirement under Article 8 § 2 raises a question of procedure as well of substance. (iv) Since the loss of one’s home is a most extreme form of interference with the right under Article 8 to respect for one’s home, any person at risk of being a victim thereof should in principle be able to have the proportionality of the measure determined by an independent tribunal in the light of the relevant principles under Article 8 of the Convention, notwithstanding that, under domestic law, he has no right of occupation. THE UNITED KINGDOM; § 95: Moreover, the Government argued that Court’s function was limited to reviewing whether or not the solution adopted by Parliament could be regarded as striking a fair balance and falling within an applicable margin of appreciation. Even though the case involved political speech, the aim was maintaining its integrity and impartiality. TV Vest had acknowledged that the lack of consensus favoured a somewhat wider margin of appreciation. It was a fine balance of competing interests, which involved the detailed consideration and rejection of less restrictive alternatives by various expert bodies and democratically-elected politicians who were peculiarly sensitive to the measures necessary to safeguard the integrity of the democratic process. It was then scrutinised by the national courts which endorsed the reasons for, and scope of, the prohibition. Accordingly, and given the margin of appreciation applicable, this Court should be slow to second-guess the solution carefully identified in a complex area by the relevant domestic bodies. The margin of appreciation left to member States regarding the requirement of paying an election deposit is a wide one.
However, such measures must not be disproportionate in terms of the means employed and the aim sought to be realised, and must not expose the parties concerned to an individual and excessive burden.
In determining the proportionality and effectiveness of the election deposit requirement in guaranteeing the right to effective, streamlined representation, several factors must be considered.
These include the importance of the right to participate in elections for the individual, the nature of the activities restricted, and the aim pursued by the restrictions.
In spheres involving the application of electoral policies, the Court affords the authorities considerable latitude.
Nevertheless, the procedural safeguards available to the individual are especially material in determining whether the respondent State has remained within its margin of appreciation.
The Court must examine whether the decision-making process leading to the imposition of the election deposit requirement was fair and such as to afford due respect to the interests safeguarded to the individual.
Furthermore, the Court emphasises that the choice of particular practical measures is in principle a matter that falls within the Contracting State’s margin of appreciation.
However, an impossible or disproportionate burden must not be imposed on the authorities without consideration being given to the operational choices which they must make in terms of priorities and resources.
In conclusion, the margin of appreciation applies to the requirement of paying an election deposit by allowing member States a wide latitude in identifying appropriate measures.
However, such measures must not be disproportionate or expose individuals to an excessive burden.
The Court will consider several factors when determining the proportionality and effectiveness of the election deposit requirement, including the importance of the right to participate in elections, the nature of the activities restricted, and the procedural safeguards available to the individual.

The following points emerge from the Court’s case-law (see Yordanova , cited above, § 118 (i)-(iv), with further references): (i) In spheres involving the application of social or economic policies, including housing, the Court affords the authorities considerable latitude. The Court has found that “[i]n so far as the exercise of discretion involving a multitude of local factors is inherent in the choice and implementation of planning policies, the national authorities in principle enjoy a wide margin of appreciation”. (ii) On the other hand, the margin of appreciation left to the authorities will tend to be narrower where the right at stake is crucial to the individual’s effective enjoyment of fundamental or “intimate” rights. This is the case in particular for Article 8 rights, which are rights of central importance to the individual’s identity, self-determination, physical and moral integrity, maintenance of relationships with others and a settled and secure place in the community. (iii) The procedural safeguards available to the individual will be especially material in determining whether the respondent State has remained within its margin of appreciation. In particular, the Court must examine whether the decision-making process leading to measures of interference was fair and such as to afford due respect to the interests safeguarded to the individual by Article 8. The “necessary in a democratic society” requirement under Article 8 § 2 raises a question of procedure as well of substance. (iv) Since the loss of one’s home is a most extreme form of interference with the right under Article 8 to respect for one’s home, any person at risk of being a victim thereof should in principle be able to have the proportionality of the measure determined by an independent tribunal in the light of the relevant principles under Article 8 of the Convention, notwithstanding that, under domestic law, he has no right of occupation. This means, among other things, that where relevant arguments concerning the proportionality of the interference have been raised by the applicant in domestic judicial proceedings, the domestic courts should examine them in detail and provide adequate reasons (see also, in this regard, Winterstein and Others , cited above, § 76).

generations.answer:
The European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) has recognized that the requirement to pay an election deposit is a legitimate measure to ensure that only serious and genuinely interested candidates participate in elections, and that it is necessary to prevent abuses and ensure the effectiveness of the electoral process. However, this measure must be applied in a manner that is proportionate to the aim pursued and does not unduly restrict the exercise of the right to stand for election and the right to effective representation.

The margin of appreciation is a concept used by the ECtHR to determine the level of deference it will give to the decisions of national authorities in certain areas of human rights law. In the context of election deposits, the ECtHR has recognized that there is a wide margin of appreciation for the regulatory details and specific procedures for collecting and refunding election deposits, as long as they are in pursuit of a legitimate aim and are proportionate.

To ensure the proportionality of election deposit requirements, the following factors must be considered:

1. The size and amount of the deposit: The deposit should be set at a level that is not excessive in relation to the financial resources of potential candidates, particularly those from disadvantaged or marginalized groups.
2. The possibility of refund: The level of the deposit that is eventually refunded to candidates after the election should be determined, as full or partial refunds can help to mitigate the financial burden on candidates.
3. Accessibility of financing: The availability of public funding or other forms of assistance for political parties and candidates should be taken into consideration, and the deposit requirement should not unjustifiably disadvantage candidates who rely on personal funds or private donations.
4. Effectiveness: The election deposit requirement must be effective in achieving its aim of preventing frivolous or abusive candidates from standing for election, while at the same time allowing genuinely interested and well-qualified candidates to participate.
5. Transparency: The election deposit requirement and its application must be transparent and predictable, and candidates must be provided with clear and timely information about the requirements and procedures.
6. Non-discrimination: The election deposit requirement must be applied impartially and without discrimination, and should not unfairly disadvantage certain categories of candidates based on their gender, ethnicity, religion or other status.

In conclusion, the requirement to pay an election deposit is a legitimate measure to ensure the effectiveness and legitimacy of the electoral process, but it must be applied in a manner that is proportionate and does not unduly restrict the right to effective, streamlined representation. The ECtHR will give a wide margin of appreciation to national authorities in the regulatory details of the election deposit requirement, but will scrutinize the proportionality of the measure in light of the above factors.

question: In the case of a suspected terrorist seeking access to information about them in the Security Police files, what factors does the Court consider in determining whether the interests of national security and the fight against terrorism prevail over the individual's interest in accessing the information?
answer: In the case cited, the context of the ongoing trial, the terrorist threat, security requirements, the procedural safeguards in place and the existence of another channel of communication between the accused and his lawyer led the Court to find no violation of Article 8. However, in cases concerning suspected terrorists, the Court has also held that the interests of national security and the fight against terrorism prevail over the applicants’ interest in having access to information about them in the Security Police files (Segerstedt-Wiberg and Others v. Sweden, 2006, § 91)45. However, there must be adequate and effective safeguards against abuse. The Court thus takes into account the circumstances of the case, such as the nature, scope and duration of the possible measures, the grounds required for ordering them, the authorities competent to authorise, carry out and supervise them, and the kind of remedy provided by the national law 49

In support of their argument, the Government submitted a copy of the KPML(r) party programme, as adopted on 2-4 January 1993, and referred in particular to its Clauses 4, 22, 23 and 28 (see paragraph 38 above).

generations.answer:
In determining whether the interests of national security and the fight against terrorism prevail over an individual's right to access information about themselves in the Security Police files, the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) considers several factors:

1. The nature and seriousness of the threat to national security or public safety: The ECtHR will assess the potential harm that disclosure of the information could cause to national security or public safety. This includes the likelihood of the information being used for terrorist activities and the potential scale of the harm.
2. The measure's necessity and proportionality: The ECtHR will consider whether the measure is a necessary and proportionate response to the threat. This means assessing whether there are less intrusive ways of protecting national security or preventing terrorist activities that could be used instead.
3. The nature of the information: The ECtHR will consider the nature and sensitivity of the information in question. This includes whether the information is protected by other legal provisions or professional secrecy, and whether it is already in the public domain.
4. The individual's legitimate interest in the information: The ECtHR will consider the individual's legitimate interest in accessing the information, such as their need to challenge incorrect information or to establish a defense in legal proceedings.
5. The effectiveness of the domestic legal framework: The ECtHR will assess the effectiveness of the domestic legal framework for safeguarding national security and protecting individuals' rights. This includes considering whether there are adequate safeguards to ensure that the measure is not used arbitrarily or disproportionately.
6. The existence of an effective remedy: The ECtHR will consider whether there is an effective remedy available for the individual to challenge the measure and, if so, whether the remedy provides adequate protection against arbitrary or disproportionate interference with their right to access information.

These factors are not exhaustive, and the ECtHR may consider additional factors on a case-by-case basis. Ultimately, the ECtHR will balance the competing interests of national security and individual rights, taking into account the specific circumstances of each case.

HUNGARY; § 68: For the Court, it is a natural consequence of the forms taken by present-day terrorism that governments resort to cutting-edge technologies in pre-empting such attacks, including the massive monitoring of communications susceptible to containing indications of impending incidents. The techniques applied in such monitoring operations have demonstrated a remarkable progress in recent years and reached a level of sophistication which is hardly conceivable for the average citizen (see the CDT’s submissions on this point in paragraphs 49-50 above), especially when automated and systemic data collection is technically possible and becomes widespread. In the face of this progress the Court must scrutinise the question as to whether the development of surveillance methods resulting in masses of data collected has been accompanied by a simultaneous development of legal safeguards securing respect for citizens’ Convention rights. These data often compile further information about the conditions in which the primary elements intercepted by the authorities were created, such as the time and place of, as well as the equipment used for, the creation of computer files, digital photographs, electronic and text messages and the like. Indeed, it would defy the purpose of government efforts to keep terrorism at bay, thus restoring citizens’ trust in their abilities to maintain public security, if the terrorist threat were paradoxically substituted for by a perceived threat of unfettered executive power intruding into citizens’ private spheres by virtue of uncontrolled yet far-reaching surveillance techniques and prerogatives. In this context the Court also refers to the observations made by the Court of Justice of the European Union and, especially, the United Nations Special Rapporteur, emphasising the importance of adequate legislation of sufficient safeguards in the face of the authorities’ enhanced technical possibilities to intercept private information (see paragraphs 23 and 24 above).

In this way it embodies the “right to a court”, of which the right of access, that is, the right to institute proceedings before courts in civil matters, constitutes one aspect (see, as a long-established reference, Golder v. the United Kingdom, 21 February 1975, §§ 35-36, Series A no. 18, and, for more recent case-law, Mendel v. Where an individual's access is limited either by operation of law or in fact, the restriction will not be incompatible with Article 6 where the limitation does not impair the very essence of the right and where it pursues a legitimate aim, and there is a reasonable relationship of proportionality between the means employed and the aim sought to be achieved (see Ashingdane v. the United Kingdom, 28 May 1985, § 57, Series A no. 93). At the same time, in order for the right of access to a court to be effective, an individual must have a clear, practical opportunity to challenge an act that is an interference with his or her rights (see Ponomarenko v. Ukraine, no. 13156/02, § 36, 14 June 2007). The Court also underlines that in the domain of interpretation of domestic legislation, in particular, procedural rules applicable to judicial proceedings, its role is limited to verifying whether the effects of such interpretation by the domestic authorities, notably the courts, are compatible with the Convention (see Zvolský and Zvolská v. the Czech Republic, no. 46129/99, § 46, ECHR 2002IX).
